text: Supplements are one of those things that half seem like snake oil, with all sorts of unsupported claims and disclaimers about how nothing has been proven or acknowledged by the FDA and such...  And we find out it seems every other month that something that was good for us, that we were since told was bad for us, is again now supposed to be good for us...Krill oil seems to be one of those grey area things.  Fish oil as well, but not to the same extent.  There seem to be quote a few things it can help for, such as high cholesterol, PMS, and helps with things like high blood pressure.  It also helps lessen clotting, so it's often used with stroke victims.  But everything you read says "it appears" or "it may."  Hardly overwhelming statements.  Some other sites say that it's "possibly safe" for most adults when used for no more than 3 months.  Trying to find some concrete information about safe doses, I find mostly that there's not enough scientific information to determine what is considered a safe dose...  And people who are going to get surgery or other medical work done that may involve bleeding should stop taking it a few weeks prior to procedures.I take a multivitamin every day, so obviously I'm not adverse to supplements.  But the ones I take aren't the ones that go insane with the levels, since those seem to be capable of doing more harm than good.Some people complained about these having a fishy taste, or being rock hard.  I'm going to guess they may have had bad batches, since the bottle I received had neither.  Capsules were softish, just odd since they're not the normal oval capsule shape, but more rounded.  And I had no fish taste, either when taken, or later in the day.I've got no feeling of any benefit from these, but I also only got the one bottle.  It may function better with longer term use.  But I've had no side effects, I've had no aftertaste, or problems swallowing these.  A quarter per pill seemed a little steep to me, until I started comparing other brands, and suddenly the quarter per capsule seemed downright thrifty.But these have 1200mg in the daily dosage of 2 capsules.  The less "commercialized / sales pitch" sites specify that since the absorption of krill oil is so much better than that with fish oil, that the dosages are not comparable and that should be taken into consideration.  So people ought to be aiming for about 2/3 of the target dosage they had using other oils.  That puts the 1200mg up to almost twice what most places I came across said should be used in most instances for krill oil.  And if that's the case, then the 600mg single pill is apparently a good target for people trying this without any medical personnel directing them, and that then doubles the life span of a single bottle.If I suddenly start seeing any of the benefits before the bottle is expended, I'll update my review accordingly since if it actually does as claimed, then it would deserve at least another star.  But until I actually see any effectiveness, I'll stick with a neutral rating.
